content.description: A grungy start leads to an excellent, clean, and bulletproof arete.
content.protection: A few cams or wires to start, seven draws for the arete proper, and #3 Camalot above the arete. The rap slings need replacing.

content.description: The clean-looking spire, a semi-detached yellow-colored feature of the wall, is host to a nice clean clip-up on largely fine rock. So-so right off the ground. It can be easy to shift left and grab a rest the gap, but the line has good continuity and fine gear by staying straight up.
content.protection: Seven or eight draws and something for the chain anchor at the top.

content.description:
If you have a rope on the anchors of the

Unknown Spire

, you might check this one out.

Climb up the left side of the pillar on right-trending cracks to a body sized pod. Stem, chimney, and grunt to an interesting move right to the anchors.

A wild, overhanging, wide fingers to bomber fists/hands crack. We elected to set a top rope (2-#3friends, 1-#7 Power Cam), after looking at the bottom half of the crack. It is an inch wide crack made up of two broken quartzite bands on either side of what would be a killer fist crack (this is the crux). The crack will take gear in the 0.5-1.0" range down low, I just wouldn't trust it to hold in a fall. There are two blocks wedged into the open book, above the crack(I trundled two more, that were on top of these two, but alas the two that remain didn't want to go.)Stem past the two chock-stones, on face holds and finish the hand-crack/ramp to the top.

NOTE:

I gave this a 5.11d-12a as that is the limit of my trad. on-sight ability,(took a couple go's on TR to figure out the moves). With traffic this line may go "ground up" as a lot of the broken quartz falls out when you shove your toes into it. Even then the bottom might be a little sketchy, since the crack is so shallow.
content.protection:
TR on two #3 Friends, and a #7 Metolius.

The top can be reached by scrambling around the left or right side of the cliff, the right side is a little easier.
content.location: Upper tier, left side of crag.

content.description: My second favorite line on the wall. Climb on good holds up to the right side of the spire, just left of a pine tree. Stem the corner up to a ledge a brief fist crack. work your way up to the tiny roof and turn it via cracks on either side. Clip the anchors or continue up.
content.protection:
I managed to get a #2 Ball Nut and a #1 TCU into the lower dihedral, but I wouldn't want to fall here.

Standard rack.
content.location:
On the right side of

Unknown Spire

.

content.description:
This route shares its start with

Curving Corner

, and branches right at the huge, detached flake. Climb up out and around the left side of the flake, I elected to jam and smear as opposed to pulling out on the bottom of the flake. It feels pretty bomber, but I guess you never know.

Once you gain the top of the flake, head left to an interesting OW for ten feet and the top.
content.protection: Standard rack, A couple extra hand/fist sized if you choose to sew it up. #4-5 BD for the OW.
content.location: Route furthest right on the  wall.

content.description:
Glow Bug 5.8R.

This route climbs the funky 5.6 choss up to a detached pillar just below the second tier. Pick a line up to the pillar that looks solidish, and Ow/stem/hug the pillar to its top. Step across to the wall and make one good face move to the ledge. Walk back to the  12 foot tall hand crack and climb to the top.
content.location: Begin at the low point of the main wall proper, on the far left side.

content.description:
Climb the broken base of

Wolly Bugger

/

Orange Zonker

up to the right-facing corner. Climb a thin, wandering flake up to a ledge and finish up the juggy OW in the back corner.
content.location:
Left of

Orange Zonker

, shares the same start.
